Chuikov joined the Red Army in 1918 and fought in the Russian Civil War. He was promoted to the rank of colonel in 1938 and was appointed commander of the 13th Mechanized Corps in 1940.

During the Battle of Stalingrad, Chuikov commanded the 62nd Army, which was responsible for defending the southern part of the city. He was credited with saving the city from complete destruction and ensuring the Soviet victory.

After the war, Chuikov continued to serve in the Soviet military and was promoted to the rank of general in 1945. He died on January 18, 1982, in Moscow, Russia.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output:
G. Venugopal is an Indian politician and a member of the Indian National Congress. He is a member of the 16th Lok Sabha of India. He represents the Tirupur constituency of Tamil Nadu and is its current president.

## Early life

G. Venugopal was born on 15 August 1959 in Tirupur, Tamil Nadu. He is a graduate in commerce from the University of Madras.

## Career

G. Venugopal is a member of the Indian National Congress. He was elected to the Lok Sabha from Tirupur in 2019. He is the president of the Tirupur district unit of the Indian National Congress.

## Personal life

G. Venugopal is married to S. Sathyavathi. He has two sons and a daughter.

## External links

* Official biographical sketch in Parliament of India website

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output:
Rangi Te Kanawa was a New Zealand Māori leader and politician. He was born in 1850 in the Bay of Islands, and was the son of Te Kanawa and his wife, Te Kahui. He was educated at the Wesleyan Mission School in Auckland, and later became a teacher at the Te Aute College.

In 1875, Te Kanawa was elected to the New Zealand House of Representatives as the representative for the Bay of Islands electorate. He was re-elected in 1876, and served until 1879. During his time in Parliament, he was a member of the Native Lands Committee.

In 1881, Te Kanawa was appointed as the Native Lands Commissioner for the Bay of Islands. He held this position until 1884, when he was succeeded by William Preece.

In 1885, Te Kanawa was appointed as the Native Lands Commissioner for the Northland region. He held this position until 1889, when he was succeeded by William Preece again.
